episodeTitle: The Fierce Battle Coming to the End - Lucy vs. Chinjao
episodeTitleJapanese: 激戦決着!ルーシーVS チンジャオ!
description: Luffy's battle with Don Chinjao reaches its climax in Block C of the Corrida Colosseum tournament. After a fierce exchange of Busoshoku and Conqueror's Haki, a flashback reveals how Chinjao lost his legendary drill-shaped head to Garp. In the present, Luffy's final punch not only defeats Chinjao but also restores his drill head, securing Luffy's victory in Block C.

events.title: Luffy and Chinjao's Haki Clash Intensifies
events.description: The final two competitors of Block C, Lucy (Luffy) and Don Chinjao, clash with both Busoshoku Haki and Conqueror's Haki. The powerful collision of their wills knocks out spectators in the stands, demonstrating the incredible strength of both fighters.
events.significance: This is one of the first times Luffy's Conqueror's Haki is shown clashing equally with another powerful user, demonstrating his growth as a fighter since the timeskip.

events.title: Chinjao's Drill Head Glory
events.description: A flashback reveals Don Chinjao in his prime, known as 'Chinjao the Drill.' His extremely long and pointy head functioned as a powerful drill capable of breaking through the ice continent that protected his clan's treasure - several hundred years worth of accumulated wealth.
events.significance: This backstory establishes Chinjao's legendary status and explains the source of his grudge against Garp and, by extension, Luffy. It also introduces the Jewel Ice Sheet location.

quotes.text: The key to getting into the room is my drill head.
quotes.speaker: Chinjao
quotes.context: Explaining how his head was the only way to access his clan's treasure vault

events.title: Garp vs Chinjao Flashback Battle
events.description: Thirty years in the past, Chinjao and Monkey D. Garp meet and duel. Garp throws a Haki-imbued fist to counter Chinjao's Haki-imbued headbutt. Both warriors put all their strength into these attacks, but Garp emerges victorious when his punch pushes Chinjao's pointy forehead back into his skull, completely flattening it.
events.significance: This flashback demonstrates Garp's incredible strength in his prime and establishes the deep-seated grudge Chinjao holds against Garp's family, which extends to Luffy as Garp's grandson.

events.title: Chinjao Loses Access to His Treasure
events.description: After his head is flattened by Garp, Chinjao returns to the Jewel Ice Sheet but discovers he can no longer break through the ice to reach his treasure. Despite repeated attempts, his flattened head lacks the drilling power needed to pierce the ice. This loss of his treasure leads to Chinjao losing his fame, money, and power.
events.significance: This moment explains the depth of Chinjao's hatred for Garp and why he initially wanted to kill Luffy as revenge. It also sets up the emotional payoff when Luffy later restores his drill head.

quotes.text: I will never forgive him or even his grandchildren!
quotes.speaker: Chinjao
quotes.context: Chinjao's curse upon Garp after losing access to his treasure

events.title: Chinjao Mentions Ace's Death
events.description: During the battle, Chinjao berates Rayleigh for believing Luffy could lead the way for the new generation, calling him out of touch. He then praises the Marines for killing Ace, calling him 'the most evil one of the lot.' This comment angers Luffy immensely, fueling his determination in the fight.
events.significance: This is a powerful callback to Ace's death at Marineford and shows how deeply the loss still affects Luffy. It also demonstrates how Ace's death reverberates throughout the pirate world.

quotes.text: You're not too bad but if a guy like Rayleigh chose a brat at this level as the flag bearer for this generation, he's not as smart as he used to be. The Marines were smart when they squelched the most evil one of the lot: Ace.
quotes.speaker: Chinjao
quotes.context: Chinjao's provocative statement about Luffy's potential and Ace's death

events.title: Luffy Restores Chinjao's Drill Head
events.description: In the climactic moment of the battle, Luffy delivers a powerful punch imbued with Busoshoku Haki directly to Chinjao's head. The impact of Luffy's attack not only defeats Chinjao but also pushes his skull back out, restoring his legendary drill-shaped head to its original pointed form.
events.significance: This moment demonstrates Luffy's incredible Haki mastery and physical strength, showing that he has reached a level comparable to his grandfather Garp in his prime. It also transforms Chinjao's grudge into gratitude.

events.title: Lucy Wins Block C
events.description: After Luffy's devastating punch, Chinjao falls unconscious and crashes headfirst into the colosseum platform, breaking it into two pieces. The referee declares Lucy (Luffy) the winner of Block C of the Corrida Colosseum tournament, earning him a spot in the finals to compete for the Mera Mera no Mi.
events.significance: Luffy's victory in Block C advances him to the final round of the tournament, bringing him one step closer to obtaining Ace's Devil Fruit. This victory also earns him the respect of a legendary pirate.

quotes.text: Lucy is declared the winner of Block C!
quotes.speaker: Announcer
quotes.context: The official announcement of Luffy's victory

quotes.text: I will never forgive him or even his grandchildren!
quotes.speaker: Chinjao
quotes.context: Cursing Garp after losing access to his treasure

quotes.text: You're not too bad but if a guy like Rayleigh chose a brat at this level as the flag bearer for this generation, he's not as smart as he used to be. The Marines were smart when they squelched the most evil one of the lot: Ace.
quotes.speaker: Chinjao

quotes.text: Lucy is declared the winner of Block C!
quotes.speaker: Announcer
quotes.context: Announcing Luffy's victory in the tournament

themes.description: The episode explores how the actions of the previous generation affect the current one, with Garp's past actions creating both obstacles and opportunities for Luffy.
themes.symbolism: Chinjao's drill head represents both the weight of past grudges and the potential for redemption through the new generation.

themes.description: Luffy not only defeats Chinjao but also helps him overcome his physical limitation, transforming an enemy's hatred into gratitude.
themes.symbolism: The restoration of Chinjao's drill head symbolizes how Luffy can surpass and heal the wounds created by previous generations.

themes.description: Chinjao's mention of Ace's death reminds viewers that Luffy still carries the pain of losing his brother, even as he grows stronger.
themes.symbolism: Luffy's anger at Chinjao's words shows that his emotional wounds from Marineford have not fully healed.

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy demonstrates his growth in both Haki mastery and physical strength, showing he has reached a level comparable to legends like Garp. His emotional reaction to Ace's mention shows his wounds from Marineford still run deep.
keyActions: Delivers the decisive punch that defeats Chinjao and restores his drill head
Wins Block C of the tournament

characterSpotlights.development: Through flashbacks, we learn the depth of Chinjao's fall from legendary pirate to bitter old man seeking revenge. His defeat by Luffy paradoxically gives him hope again by restoring what Garp took from him.
keyActions: Reveals his backstory about losing his drill head to Garp
Provokes Luffy by mentioning Ace's death
Has his drill head restored by Luffy's punch
quotes: I will never forgive him or even his grandchildren!

You're not too bad but if a guy like Rayleigh chose a brat at this level as the flag bearer for this generation, he's not as smart as he used to be. The Marines were smart when they squelched the most evil one of the lot: Ace.

characterSpotlights.development: Garp's incredible strength in his prime is showcased as he defeats the legendary Chinjao with a single punch, permanently altering the course of Chinjao's life.
keyActions: Battles Chinjao thirty years in the past
Flattens Chinjao's drill head with a Haki-imbued punch

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime extends the battle sequences between Luffy and Chinjao with additional combat animation not present in the manga.
The flashback sequences of Chinjao's past are more detailed and extended in the anime, showing more of his crew's reactions.

trivia.fact: This episode covers the end of Chapter 718 and most of Chapter 719 from the manga.
The episode rating on IMDB is 8.4/10, indicating strong positive reception from fans.
This is one of the few times in the series where Luffy's Conqueror's Haki directly clashes with another user's Conqueror's Haki in an evenly matched battle.
The restoration of Chinjao's drill head by Luffy mirrors how Garp destroyed it, creating a symbolic parallel between grandfather and grandson.
